title: How to Get Rid of Acne on the Buttocks

steps.title: Butt acne isn’t acne at all—it’s actually called folliculitis.
steps.content: Butt acne isn’t acne at all—it’s actually called folliculitis. This is a fancy term for when your hair follicles get infected from fungus, bacteria, or yeast. It typically looks like a small, irritated bump, similar to standard acne. Medical experts say that these spots usually feel uncomfortable and possibly itchy. [1] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source

steps.title: Yes, it’s perfectly normal.
steps.content: Yes, it’s perfectly normal. Medical professionals agree that folliculitis is very common—since it’s caused by inflamed hair follicles, just about anyone can deal with it. You have nothing to be upset or ashamed about if you notice these uncomfortable bumps. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Your folliculitis might be caused by an infection.
steps.content: Your folliculitis might be caused by an infection. Many cases of folliculitis can actually be chalked up to a bacterial infection, which can look like a large boil. It may also be caused by a yeast, fungal, or viral infection—however, bacteria is the most common culprit when it comes to butt acne. [3] X Trustworthy Source DermNet NZ Online clinical resource website written and run by dermatologists providing evidence-based information about dermatology and skin health Go to source

steps.title: It might be caused by a lot of friction.
steps.content: It might be caused by a lot of friction. If you wear really tight clothing, it might be chafing against your skin, which creates the “acne.” Take a look at some of your favorite shorts, pants, or other bottoms—if they’re pretty skin-tight, then they might be causing the issue. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Your hair follicles might be clogged.
steps.content: Your hair follicles might be clogged. Your hair follicles might be blocked if you use a really creamy moisturizer or ointment for your skin. If you use a creamy moisturizer all over your skin, then that might be causing your folliculitis. [5] X Research source If you tend to sweat a lot, that may also be part of the problem.

steps.title: Visit a doctor or dermatologist if you think you have an infection.
steps.content: Visit a doctor or dermatologist if you think you have an infection. They can prescribe an antibiotic cream to help you tackle the bacteria at the source. Don’t worry—you shouldn’t have to take antibiotic pills for this unless your infection is really severe. [6] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source A doctor can confirm if it’s an infection, and if so, what’s causing it. If bacteria is causing the problem, then you’ll probably need antibiotic cream. However, fungal infections can be treated with over-the-counter creams and ointments.

steps.title: Call your doctor if you develop serious symptoms.
steps.content: Call your doctor if you develop serious symptoms. Keep tabs on how you’re feeling—butt acne is typically harmless, but in more serious cases, folliculitis can lead to fever, nausea, chills, and more. If you’re feeling under the weather, call your doctor for guidance. [7] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Clean the skin with a benzoyl peroxide wash.
steps.content: Clean the skin with a benzoyl peroxide wash. Pick up an acne wash with benzoyl peroxide as one of the main ingredients—this will kill off any bad bacteria in the area. [8] X Research source Dampen the skin with a wet towel, and massage the product onto the affected area. After 1-2 minutes, rinse off the product and pat the skin dry with a towel. [9] X Trustworthy Source National Health Service (UK) Public healthcare system of the UK Go to source You can use this wash up to twice a day. Most people see results within 4 weeks, but it may depend on the case.

steps.title: Soak the area with a vinegar compress to ease the irritation.
steps.content: Soak the area with a vinegar compress to ease the irritation. Mix 1.4 cups (320 mL) of water with 1 US tbsp (15 mL) of white vinegar. Dip a clean cloth in the mixture and sit on the compress for 5-10 minutes. You can make and use this compress up to 6 times each day. [10] X Research source

steps.title: Take a twice a week if you have bacterial folliculitis.
steps.content: Take a twice a week if you have bacterial folliculitis. Fill your tub about halfway with warm water, and then stir in 1 ⁄ 4 c (59 mL) of . Relax and unwind in the bath for 10 to 15 minutes, and then rinse yourself off with clean water. [11] X Research source This might stop the bacteria from returning again.

steps.title: Wait up to 2 weeks and see if it goes away.
steps.content: Wait up to 2 weeks and see if it goes away. If your folliculitis is pretty mild, then it might clear up on its own. In some cases, it might go away within 7 to 10 days. [12] X Research source

steps.title: Don’t scratch or pick at the skin.
steps.content: Don’t scratch or pick at the skin. It can be really tempting to pick or “pop” the acne in that area. Unfortunately, this will only make things worse in the long run. [13] X Research source

steps.title: Wear loose clothes instead of skin tight garments.
steps.content: Wear loose clothes instead of skin tight garments. Friction and folliculitis tend to go hand hand, and tight shorts and pants might be doing you more harm than good. Instead, rifle through your closet for pants, shorts, and other bottoms that fit comfortably, and don’t rub against your skin quite as much. [14] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Take a shower with gentle soap right after you exercise.
steps.content: Take a shower with gentle soap right after you exercise. After a tough workout, bacteria may be trapped on your skin. Gently wash and rinse off the skin with a mild cleanser, so this bacteria doesn’t turn into folliculitis later on. [15] X Research source Always change out of your workout clothes right after you’ve exercised. [16] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Dermatology Professional organization made of over 20,000 certified dermatologists Go to source

steps.title: Ditch any oil-rich products from your beauty routine.
steps.content: Ditch any oil-rich products from your beauty routine. Body oils tend to get bacteria stuck in your pores, which can lead to folliculitis. Instead, look for lotions, creams, and other skin products that aren’t as likely to clog up your follicles. [17] X Research source Look for products with “non-comedogenic” or “oil-free” on the label. [18] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Dermatology Professional organization made of over 20,000 certified dermatologists Go to source
